awd_titl_txt: REU Site: Chemistry 360 degrees: A Comprehensive Research and Career Development Experience @UBChemistry
awd_abstract_narration:
This Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) site award to the State University of New York (SUNY) at Buffalo, located in Buffalo, NY, supports the training of 10 students for 10 weeks during the summers of 2019-2021. In this program, funded by the Division of Chemistry in the Mathematical and Physical Science Directorate, Professors Jason B. Benedict, Timothy R. Cook and colleagues host an REU site covering a broad range of chemical research and career development with a focus on the leveraging of digital platforms. Participants engage in research encompassing core chemical science areas including inorganic, analytical, biomedical or polymeric chemistry. Alongside chemical research, the program includes industrial site visits to local chemical and biochemical companies, seminars to develop and improve 'soft skills', and training on the use of digital platforms to advance research and career development. In total, these activities prepare UB Chem360 REU participants for graduate school and beyond.

Individual participants' research projects include synthesis of porous nanomaterials, development of new enantioselective reactions, metal ion complex binding to nucleic acids, photo-responsive crystalline materials, catalysis of ene-yne reactions, ligand-driven enzyme catalysis, charge transfer at semi-conductor interfaces, and structure prediction of novel materials.  Other areas of research include studying the role of lipids in cell processes, physicochemical characteristics of novel chromatographic materials, imaging of hydrogel and polymer surfaces and self-assembly of nanoscopic metallacycles. These independent and interdisciplinary research projects, facilitated by SUNY at Buffalo faculty and graduate student mentors, provide participants with experiences in problem solving and scientific discovery. This site puts an emphasis on recruiting students from two-year colleges and students who are underrepresented in chemistry. Combined with 'soft skills' and digital platform training, this program prepares participants to pursue advanced degrees and enter the chemistry workforce.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The goals of the REU Site: Chemistry 360 degrees: A Comprehensive Research and Career Development Experience @UBChemistry at the Department of Chemistry at the University at Buffalo, the State University of New York were: (1) Enhance the impact of undergraduate research programs by integrating and improving impactful student activities of previous REU programs (interdisciplinary research, global sustainability, and sustained engagement), (2) provide participants with a comprehensive review of potential career paths, (3) develop and improve ‘soft skills’ critical for professional success, (4) training on the use of digital platforms (LinkedIn and Twitter) to advance both research and career development, (5) continue our strong efforts to provide students from underrepresented groups with research opportunities and ultimately to increase the number of students from these groups in STEM fields. Thirty-two NSF-funded students and seven additional undergraduate students funded through other programs in the Department of Chemistry participated in the NSF REU program from 2019-2022. The program was suspended in 2020 due to the COVID-19 pandemic. The overall demographics for the three summer cycles of the REU program for NSF-funded participants (all participating undergraduates in parentheses) were: female 63% (62%); underrepresented minorities 44% (54%). External evaluation of our program found that participants reported strong gains in their research skills, confidence in their ability to conduct research, and their understanding of scientific ethics. Importantly, students found their mentors to be very supportive and helpful and many expressed positive comments about the mentorship they received through the NSF REU program.
